Albedo ( α) is not constant, but rather depends on surface cover (fresh snow, firn, bare ice, supraglacial debris and so on.) and zenith angle 56 57. To determine the albedo of bare ice at the location of AWS01, we take the ratio of measured upwelling shortwave ( K ↑) to global downwelling shortwave ( K ↓) radiation
at all time steps in the selected 2-year record. We (1) eliminate those measurements taken at the lowest solar azimuth angles (all winter measurements and all records that are >5 h from solar noon), (2) disregard records within 10 days following a fresh snowfall event and (3) compute the mean (0.45). We purposely bias our albedo estimate toward values near solar noon (highest zenith angles) because the sensitivity of the land surface energy balance to albedo is the highest during periods of high K↓. We disregard the data following fresh snowfall events in order to include in the mean of only those measurements made over bare ice. We do not model the zenith angle dependency of albedo. We address the modelled albedo change through time as a function of changing surface type below.
